articles.headline: Kevin Reilly, Head of Fox’s Programming, Is Stepping Down
articles.snippet: Mr. Reilly is stepping down as head of entertainment programming after three consecutive years of steep declines in ratings for “American Idol,” a show crucial to the network’s profits.
articles.abstract: Mr. Reilly is stepping down as head of entertainment programming after three consecutive years of steep declines in ratings for “American Idol,” a show crucial to the network’s profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: The drastic falloff of “American Idol” has cost the Fox network dearly in terms of ratings and profits, and now it has contributed to the loss of its top entertainment executive, Kevin Reilly.

articles.headline: Doctor Shortage Is Cited in Delays at V.A. Hospitals
articles.snippet: With too few doctors to handle a swelling patient population of veterans, hospital officials were under pressure to excel in the annual performance reviews used to determine raises, an inspector general’s report found.
articles.abstract: With too few doctors to handle a swelling patient population of veterans, hospital officials were under pressure to excel in the annual performance reviews used to determine raises, an inspector general’s report found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Phyllis Hollenbeck, a primary care physician, took a job at the Veterans Affairs medical center in Jackson, Miss., in 2008 expecting fulfilling work and a lighter patient load than she had had in private practice.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: After Crisis, a New Spirit of Reining In the Banks
articles.snippet: Many people believe there is not enough regulation of banks and they want tougher rules and more stringent enforcement of those rules.
articles.abstract: Many people believe there is not enough regulation of banks and they want tougher rules and more stringent enforcement of those rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is widely believed that there has long been something that could be called a regulator-banker complex. People with similar views on the proper level of regulation move back and forth between the two groups. Their hats change, but not their policy preferences.

articles.headline: Global Investors Looking for Real Estate Bargains Flock to Spain
articles.snippet: Private equity firms and banks are descending on Spain, teaming up and competing for huge loan portfolios left over from 2008’s market collapse.
articles.abstract: Private equity firms and banks are descending on Spain, teaming up and competing for huge loan portfolios left over from 2008’s market collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: As one of the most moribund housing markets in Europe, Spain has become a magnet for global bargain hunters. Real estate prices are down as much as 50 percent from their peak during a housing bubble, and investors from Asia to the United States and Britain are flocking to Spain to try to catch the uptick.

articles.headline: Right to Be Forgotten? Not That Easy
articles.snippet: A recent court ruling in Europe has accelerated requests that Internet search companies remove links to individuals’ data. Once a contested item is online, however, the genie will not easily go back in the bottle.
articles.abstract: A recent court ruling in Europe has accelerated requests that Internet search companies remove links to individuals’ data. Once a contested item is online, however, the genie will not easily go back in the bottle.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Eoin McKeogh knows how hard it can be to make the Internet forget.

articles.headline: In Puerto Rico, Cocaine Gains Access to U.S.
articles.snippet: Increasingly thwarted by scrutiny on the United States-Mexico border, drug smugglers are opting to move their merchandise through Puerto Rico instead.
articles.abstract: Increasingly thwarted by scrutiny on the United States-Mexico border, drug smugglers are opting to move their merchandise through Puerto Rico instead.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — With its navigation lights off, the 35-foot speedboat raced north toward Puerto Rico one night this month, its two large engines at full throttle. Above, a Coast Guard helicopter chased it and then let loose a few warning shots. But the boat roared ahead. Then, thwack, the crew on the copter shot out one of engines.

articles.headline: Foreign Jihadis Fighting in Syria Pose Risk in West
articles.snippet: As many as 3,000 Westerners are believed to have gone to Syria to fight, prompting more aggressive efforts by governments to take action against domestic threats.
articles.abstract: As many as 3,000 Westerners are believed to have gone to Syria to fight, prompting more aggressive efforts by governments to take action against domestic threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two years ago, a young man who now calls himself Abu Muhajir slipped into Syria with a few friends and $80,000, forsaking what he said was a job as a high school science teacher in North America to wage jihad.

articles.headline: Companies Quietly Apply Biofuel Tools to Household Products
articles.snippet: Companies are beginning to use synthetic biology in producing cosmetics and household cleansers, but there is reluctance in how much to publicize it.
articles.abstract: Companies are beginning to use synthetic biology in producing cosmetics and household cleansers, but there is reluctance in how much to publicize it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumer products containing ingredients made using an advanced form of engineering known as synthetic biology are beginning to show up more often on grocery and department store shelves.

articles.headline: For Lessons About Class, a Field Trip Takes Students Home
articles.snippet: By visiting classmates’ homes during the school day, 4- and 5-year-olds at the Manhattan Country School learn to celebrate their differences.
articles.abstract: By visiting classmates’ homes during the school day, 4- and 5-year-olds at the Manhattan Country School learn to celebrate their differences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of us have more toys and bigger homes than others. We all have a lot in common, but there are certain things that make us unique, too. Let’s talk about those things and celebrate them, even.

articles.headline: V.A. Chief Resigns in Face of Furor on Delayed Care
articles.snippet: Eric Shinseki’s resignation leaves behind a sprawling bureaucracy embroiled in scandal and burdened with a decades-old legacy of overwhelmed facilities and management failures that his successor must now confront.
articles.abstract: Eric Shinseki’s resignation leaves behind a sprawling bureaucracy embroiled in scandal and burdened with a decades-old legacy of overwhelmed facilities and management failures that his successor must now confront.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Eric Shinseki resigned as secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs on Friday, leaving behind a sprawling bureaucracy embroiled in scandal and burdened with a decades-old legacy of overwhelmed facilities and management failures that his successor must now confront.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Richard A. Oppel Jr
